qas.question: What property of bitumen makes it difficult to move through pipelines?
What industry is capable of refining bitumen directly into gasoline without preprocessing?
Why do refineries like to buy bitumen instead of synthetic oil?
How much Canadian bitumen was exported to the US by 2015?

plausible_answers.text: Venezuelan extra-heavy and Mexican heavy oil

qas.question: What type of oils does Canadian bitumen differ substantially from?
Other than Mexican extra-heavy oil, what type of oil does Canadian bitumen not differ greatly from?
Other than Venezuelan-light oil, what type of oil does Canadian bitumen not differ greatly from?
What type of oils does American bitumen not differ substantially from?
In what areas is this uncommon?

context: Canadian bitumen does not differ substantially from oils such as <b4_0><b5_0><b7_0>Venezuelan extra-heavy<b5_0/> and <b6_0>Mexican heavy<b7_0/><b6_0/> oil<b4_0/> in chemical composition, and the real difficulty is moving the <a0_0>extremely viscous<a0_0/> bitumen through oil pipelines to the refinery. Many <a1_0>modern oil refineries<a1_0/> are extremely sophisticated and can process non-upgraded bitumen directly into products such as gasoline, diesel fuel, and refined asphalt without any preprocessing. This is particularly common in areas such as the <b8_0>US Gulf coast<b8_0/>, where refineries were designed to process Venezuelan and Mexican oil, and in areas such as the US Midwest where refineries were rebuilt to process heavy oil as domestic light oil production declined. Given the choice, such heavy oil refineries usually prefer to buy bitumen rather than synthetic oil because the <a2_0>cost is lower<a2_0/>, and in some cases because they prefer to produce more diesel fuel and less gasoline. By 2015 Canadian production and exports of non-upgraded bitumen exceeded that of synthetic crude oil at over 1.3 million barrels (210×10^3 m3) per day, of which about <a3_0>65%<a3_0/> was exported to the United States.
